videoData.title: How to win at evolution and survive a mass extinction
videoData.socialTitle: How to win at evolution and survive a mass extinction

recommendations.blurb: Further reading on paleobiology curated by Lauren Sallan

recItems.blurb: This lively book for a popular audience covers our current understanding of the all major mass extinctions in the history of life and what they collectively mean for the future. Peter Brannen interviewed numerous paleobiologists, geologists and other investigators behind the discoveries, tagging along on fieldwork and visiting their labs. As a result, it’s part travelogue, part hard data and part sociology of science, resulting in a deep and multifaceted view of the state of the art that's also fun!
recItems.headline: *The Ends of The World*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: For more detailed information about gains and losses in the evolutionary history of fishes, read this synthesis of their extensive fossil record. While this article is from five years ago, most of the material is still relevant, if only for lack of workers!
recItems.headline: "Five Hundred Million Years of Extinction and Recovery"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: For more information about the weird and wonderful fishes featured on my slides, or just more beautiful paleoart, refer to this colorful introduction by John Long (Flinders University). Prof. Long is eminent paleoichthyologist who has helped flesh out "The Age of Fishes" through numerous discoveries and a prolific author of science books for a general audience. This book is a great choice for anyone with an interest in paleontology, or life in general.
recItems.headline: *The Rise of Fishes: 500 Million Years of Evolution*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
John A. Long
Johns Hopkins University, 2010

recItems.blurb: Refer to this classic textbook series for a more thorough introduction to vertebrate paleontology as it is currently practiced, and our present take on the history of vertebrate kind. Prof. Benton (Bristol) helped revolutionize the study of long-term evolution (macroevolution) and mass extinction in vertebrates. Here, he summarizes decades of breakthroughs, cutting-edge techniques and the full diversity of fossil vertebrates in an accessible way.
recItems.headline: *Vertebrate Palaeontology, 4th Edition*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

nodes.whoTheyAre: TED Senior Fellow Lauren Sallan is a paleobiologist using a wide variety of data and methods to reveal how biodiversity changes at scales beyond human observation (macroevolution).
nodes.whyListen:
Lauren Sallan uses the vast record of living and fossil marine ecosystems as a global, "deep time" database. She combines cutting-edge analytics with experimental results and natural observations to reveal why some species persist and diversify while others die off, and how life responds to environmental challenges big and small. She has used this multidisciplinary approach to discover the largest, "sixth" mass extinction of vertebrates, reveal the environmental origins of our earliest ancestors and show how new fish predators can shift prey ecology at global scales.

Sallan is the founder and head of the Marine Macroevolution Unit at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST), Japan, where she leads an international team of multidisciplinary scientists. She was previously the Martin Meyerson Assistant Professor in Interdisciplinary Studies at the University of Pennsylvania, and became a TED Fellow in 2017 and a TED Senior Fellow in 2019. Her research has been published in outlets such as Science, Nature, PNAS and Current Biology, as well featured by The New York Times, the BBC, Forbes, the New Scientist, the Discovery Channel and others.

videoData.description: Congratulations! By being here, alive, you are one of history's winners -- the culmination of a success story four billion years in the making. The other 99 percent of species who have ever lived on earth are dead -- killed by fire, flood, asteroids, ice, heat and the cold math of natural selection. How did we get so lucky, and will we continue to win? In this short, funny talk, paleobiologist and TED Fellow Lauren Sallan shares insights on how your ancestors' survival through mass extinction made you who you are today.

cues.text: a member of a growing species,

you are one of history's
greatest winners --

the culmination of a success story
four billion years in the making.

the 99 percent of species
who have ever lived,
and the cold math of natural selection.

You are here because
of golden opportunities

The same is true
of your co-winners and relatives.
How did we all get so lucky?

I am a fish paleobiologist
who uses big data --

to study how some species win
and others lose.
So, we must speak with the dead.
How do we make dead fishes talk?

Museums contain multitudes
of beautiful fish fossils,

when combined with the larger
number of ugly, broken fossils,
and reduced to ones and zeros.

I can trawl a 500-million-year database
for evolutionary patterns.
fish forms can be captured by coordinates

and transformed to reveal
major pathways of change

Here is the story
of the winners and losers

of just one pivotal event
I discovered using fossil data.

six times as long ago
as the last dinosaur --

Armored predators
with razor-edge jaws dominated

alongside huge fishes
with arm bones in their fins.

Crab-like fishes scuttled
across the sea floor.

The few ray-fin relatives
of salmon and tuna
cowered at the bottom of the food chain.

The few early sharks
lived offshore in fear.

Your few four-legged ancestors,
the tetrapods,
No, it is a good thing.
96 percent of all fish species died

during the Hangenberg event,
359 million years ago:
an interval of fire and ice.

A crowded world was disrupted
and swept away.

Now, you might think
that's the end of the story.

The mighty fell,
the meek inherited the earth,
But winning is not that simple.

The handful of survivors
came from many groups --
all greatly outnumbered by their own dead.

They ranged from top predator
to bottom-feeder,
It merely leveled the playing field.

What really counted was what survivors did
over the next several million years

The former overlords
should have had an advantage.

keeping what had always worked,
and biding their time.
Yet they merely persisted for a while,
They were too stuck in their ways

A few of the long-suffering ray-fins,
sharks and four-legged tetrapods

and won the future
for their 60,000 living species,
Winning is not about random events

Rather, survivors went down alternative,
evolutionary pathways.
while others became dead fish walking.

how these pathways to victory and defeat
repeat across time.

My lab has already compiled thousands
upon thousands of dead fishes,

that your ancestors' survival
through mass extinction,
and their responses in the aftermath
made you who you are today.
What does this tell us for the future?
As long as a handful of species survive,

The versatile and the lucky
will not just replace what was lost,
It just might take several million years.

footnotes.annotation:
> You are one of history's greatest winners -- the culmination of a success story four billion years in the making.

Determining the origin date for life is difficult, given that we are looking for fossils of bacteria or their chemical signatures in the rocks. However, evidence suggests that the common ancestor of all living things existed about four billion years ago, meaning your ancestors have survived and thrived for that long, an unbroken chain.

> The losers, the 99 percent of species who have ever lived, are dead -- killed by fire, flood, asteroids, predation, starvation, ice, heat and the cold math of natural selection.

Charles Marshall at Berkeley [recently estimated](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-017-0165) that 156,860 species of mammals have existed since the end-Cretaceous extinction that wiped out the dinosaurs. We have 5,500 living mammal species today, meaning 96 percent are dead. Add in global crises, mass extinctions, and consider earlier groups that are completely dead (like our relatives, the multituberculate mammals) and 99 percent is an underestimate!

> The 34,000 kinds of fishes.

New fishes are discovered every day, so this a certainly a low estimate. You can keep track of the numbers at [Fishbase] (http://www.fishbase.org/search.php).

> I can trawl a 500-million-year database for evolutionary patterns.

Fishes, being ancestral to all living vertebrates, first show up at spectacular fossil sites such as the Burgess Shale in Canada and Chengjiang in China about 525 million years ago. They were members of the "Cambrian Explosion," a short period in which many modern groups appear in the fossil record.

> For example, fish forms can be captured by coordinates and transformed to reveal major pathways of change and trends through time.

This method is called "[geometric morphometrics](http://www.virtual-anthropology.com/virtual-anthropology/compare/geometric-morphometrics/)" and allows us to compare shapes in an objective way. We can then reduce and rank the species to create a "morphospace," or a plot showing the main ways in which animal shapes have innovated and changed through evolution. We can also use this to compare the shape diversity (disparity) of different groups.) The example shown here is from my study comparing the timing of the evolutionary change of [head and tail shapes in fishes](http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/279/1735/2025).

> Here is the story of the winners and losers of just one pivotal event I discovered using fossil data.

For more information on the discovery of this previously unrecognized event, see the original paper in [*PNAS*](http://www.pnas.org/content/107/22/10131.full.pdf) and this [*LA Times*](http://articles.latimes.com/2010/may/17/science/la-sci-fish-20100518) article

> Armored predators with razor-edge jaws dominated alongside huge fishes with arm bones in their fins.

These are placoderms (Dunkleosteus up front, Bothriolepis at the end), a diverse group of armored early fishes that did everything everywhere, and lobe-finned fishes, our own relatives including lungfishes and coelacanths.

> 96 percent of all fish species died during the Hangenberg event, 359 million years ago: an interval of fire and ice.

The Hangenberg event itself had multiple killing blows. One involved massive global warming caused by volcanism and sea level rise, choking the shoreline and reefs in toxic waters from the deep sea. Another involved massive sea level fall, associated with the sudden appearance of ice at the Poles (first time in 80 million years!) and glaciers at latitudes now associated with the Carolinas.

> What really counted was what survivors did over the next several million years in that devastated world. The former overlords should have had an advantage. They became even larger, storing energy, investing in their young, spreading across the globe, feasting on fishes, keeping what had always worked, and biding their time.

This evolutionary strategy is often called "K-selection" and has to do with life histories. Larger animals, or other species dealing with stable but limited resources and space (K, or carrying capacity), tend to play the long game -- longer lives, longer bodies, longer generation times, longer growth, longer distances traveled. However, this strategy can limit opportunities for innovation.

> A few of the long-suffering ray-fins, sharks and four-legged tetrapods went the opposite direction. They became smaller -- living fast, dying young, eating little and reproducing rapidly.

This evolutionary strategy is called "r-selection" and falls at the other end of the life history scale. Smaller animals, or other species dealing with future uncertainty, tend to put all their energy in reproduction (r), the equivalent of buying lottery tickets or throwing ideas at the wall.

> They tried new foods, different homes, strange heads and weird bodies.

Many of the successful fishes turned into shell crushers, as shelly things were [abundant after the extinction](http://www.pnas.org/content/108/20/8335.full.pdf). Many fishes that had been marine, like lungfish, became exclusively freshwater and vice versa. The variety of head shapes, and jaw forms, in ray-finned fishes increased significantly post-extinction, and later the same thing happened with their body shapes, moving towards the diversity we see today (see above). Some of the earliest equivalents of eels, angelfishes and other classic reef forms show up at this time.

> And they found opportunity, proliferated, and won the future for their 60,000 living species, including you.

The diverse, pint-sized groups were sharks, ray-finned fishes and tetrapods, which now represent nearly all vertebrates on land and at sea. This sudden turnover from placoderm-heavy to shark and ray-fin heavy ecosystems was one of [the first markers for the extinction](http://www.pnas.org/content/107/22/10131.full.pdf) itself.

> Some found incredible success, while others became dead fish walking. A real scientific term.

The exact scientific term is "dead clade walking," a clade being a group of species with a single ancestor, and was coined by David Jablonski (Chicago). This was also title of a 2014 episode of "Elementary," which centered on [a post-asteroid dinosaur](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3459420/plotsummary?ref_=tt_ov_pl)!

> It just might take several million years.

Paleontologists such as [Doug Erwin](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v528/n7582/abs/nature16160.htm) (Smithsonian) and [Mike Benton](http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v5/n6/full/ngeo1475.html) (Bristol) has shown that recovery from mass extinction, or the time it takes for ecosystems to become fully functional and biodiversity to come back in force, can take at least 5 million years and proceeds through predictable stages. This is because of ongoing instability in the environment (including aftershocks in sea level and temperature), doomed survivors, and opportunistic species (“disaster taxa”) that take up space. It’s the equivalent of the slow return of forests after a fire, which proceeds in predictable steps.

> Thank you.

I’d like to thank my collaborators on the studies featured here: Mike Coates (Chicago), Matt Friedman (Michigan), Tom Kammer (West Virginia), Bill Ausich (Ohio State), and Andy Galimberti (Maine), who was an undergraduate working on his senior thesis. My gratitude also goes to my many, many colleagues in paleobiology who have and are laying the groundwork for a quantitative understanding of the history of life on earth.
